 ok, my one question is what's wrong with a 12 year old dating a 15 year old? My parents are 5 years apart. Now granted the difference between 45 and 50 is a bit more than from 12 and 15. But in 30 years they'll be 42 and 45.
 
 About sex, what do you have a problem with? If the both consent, use protection, love each other, what's the problem?
 
 To drinking and drugs. I know for a fact that a few kids on my baseball team at least used to drink and/or do drugs. But our baseball coach apparently helped write a new code for that stuff making extreme punishments (out for a year for first offense, next offense your whole HS career). At the beginning of the year he gave a huge lecture saying he wrote the thing so he didn't want to be embarrassed by having a baseball kid get in trouble for that. He said if he even heard a rumor of a kid drinking or doing drugs (not just a random accusation, but reasonable suspicion) they'd be off the team. I think everyone has stopped, but obviously I can't be sure, and I'm sure some will continue after baseball season.
 
 Honestly I don't know how big the alcohol/drugs problem is in high schools (and middle schools? 12 years old alcohol and drugs?). I just know I really don't care if other people do it. I won't do it so that's all I need to worry about. Also note that Myspace was originally intended for music and it is still used sometimes for that purpose. btw I don't have a myspace account.

 they don't teach their children to want to learn (as evidenced by the multitudes of children who can't find Louisianna on a map), 
 

 This is actually pretty sad. Freshman year US History we had a quiz on the states. While many people knew them all and a few only had a few problems (like mixing up New Hampshire and Vermont or Colorado and Wyoming), there were people who literally didn't even know half of them. That's pretty damn sad.
 
 

 they don't teach their children how to drive safely (as evidenced by the multitudes who die from auto accidents, 
 

 Many people don't even take it seriously. The other day there was a minivan that pulled into the parking lot at easily 30 MPH without slowing down, whipped around a sharp corner and slammed on the brakes as the van slid into the parking spot. We saw a kid behind the wheel and the mother in the passenger's seat. They got out of the car, and rather than telling the kid that's no way to park, they were all laughing, that's right laughing. The mom, the kid, and the 2 younger siblings in the back. Pretty rediculous, they are risking their own safety as well as those around them and all they can do is laugh?
 
 

 but...most of all, parents don't teach their children how to do without (as evidenced by the whining of multitudes of the little bastards).

 I always figured most of the gods represented aspects of human society
 
 Donr -< Rash youngsters, the belt of might and Mjolnr representing youthful strenght
 
 Tyr -< Matured people who seen more of the world and are more difficult to impress, losing his hand in the ruse for Fenris representing a willingness to sacrifice for his community
 
 Woden -< Represents the later stages in life, think about it: wisdom, age, grasp of the bigger picture
 
 Loki as an "anti-woden" of sorts, never really thought of it like that.

Coming from the peasant Swedish class on one side of my family we had a different take on the Odin and Thor, or Taranis in the Celtic tradition. I believe that the Celtic Taranis may have had a darker nature than that of the Norse Thor.
 
 Odin was the deity of the horse-riding nobility and we serfs thumbed our noses at the likes of him. Snotty old bastard that he was.
 
 Thor, however, was our man. Working man's hero, no pretensions, jolly good fellow with the tankard of brew and his fists, and respectful of the womenfolk.
